I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) fielded a Fact-Finding Mission in May 2004 upon 
request of the Government of Indonesia for technical assistance (TA)1 in preparing the proposed 
Water Supply and Sanitation Project (WSSP). The WSSP will assist the Government in its 
continued  effort  to improve  water  supply  and  sanitation services  for  the  urban  population, 
particularly benefiting the urban poor, and to achieve the related Millennium Development Goal 
(MDG).2 The objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, 
and terms of reference for the TA are based on the understanding reached with the Government 
during the Mission. The project framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Indonesia is urbanizing rapidly. The urban population had grown at about 4% annually 
during the last decade, compared with the average annual national growth of about 1.7%. 
Indonesia’s  urban  population  is  projected  to  increase  from  the  current  45%  of  the  total 
population to 60% by 2025, and is expected to double in absolute terms to reach 160 million by 
then.  Most  urban  public  enterprises,  which  are  tasked  to  provide  basic  services  to  urban 
dwellers, are in crisis, notably local water utilities. In many parts of Indonesia, scarce water 
resources must be allocated for both urban use and the predominant agricultural use in rural 
areas, with availability of water becoming a serious issue for many cities. The quality of these 
water resources is increasingly threatened by municipal and industrial wastewater, and the 
various forms of development in upper catchment areas affect both natural water retention and 
flash flooding.  
3.  The introduction of regional autonomy in Indonesia on 1 January 2001 has resulted in 
the devolution of substantial authority from the central Government to regional governments 
(RGs) at district and city levels (kabupaten and kota) for all aspects of local infrastructure and 
service  delivery,  including  planning,  providing,  financing,  and  managing  water  supply  and 
sanitation. However, many of the more than 300 water utilities (PDAMs) throughout Indonesia 
are barely able to provide minimum services to consumers and have connected only about 39% 
of the urban population to piped water supply. The large number of PDAMs is a concern, 
because many are too small to be ever sustainable. 
4.  The lack of sanitation services requires urgent attention that will entail rehabilitating and 
extending  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  systems,  and  priority  drainage  leading  to 
improved  urban  environments,  especially  in  low-income  areas.  The  high  incidence  of 
waterborne diseases, particularly typhoid, is a potent indicator of the problems in the sector. 
Sewerage serves less than 3% of the total urban population, and accumulation of grey water 
and other pollutants in low-lying urban areas results in severe environmental problems and 
deteriorated living conditions for many of the urban poor. The initial poverty and social analysis 
is in Appendix 2. 
5.  To improve service delivery in urban areas particularly benefiting the urban poor, ADB is 
proposing the WSSP to be approved in 2005. The TA will build on previous work carried out to 
develop the sector, and review and update previous subproject appraisal reports (SPARs).3 The 
Executing Agency, together with ADB, has disseminated information on the requirements for

6.  Besides  preparing  an  investment  project  for  urban  water  supply  and  sanitation 
infrastructure, the TA will address major sector reform issues, including technical, managerial, 
operational, financial, and institutional deficiencies, which hamper improved service delivery of 
water utilities. Widespread lack of cost recovery tariffs, compounded by a low level of revenue 
collection, results in reduced maintenance and investment capacity, deteriorating assets, and 
low service coverage and quality, all of which have a major impact on economic development, 
health, and well-being of the urban population. In addition, most of the PDAMs are heavily 
indebted. Some 220 PDAMs hold more than 400 outstanding loans with the Ministry of Finance 
(MOF), with many of the loans in arrears.  
7.  Given the low level of only about 39% of the urban population connected to piped water 
supply and the fast pace of urbanization, it will take major efforts to achieve the MDG for water 
supply and sanitation (footnote 2). The bulk of finance for the urgently needed improvements 
will  have  to  come  from  cash  generated  by  the  PDAMs,  and  from  improved  financial 
management and borrowing capacity of RGs. Enhanced self-financing capacity of PDAMs is 
closely related to improved governance in terms of corporatization and increased managerial 
autonomy. Measures to improve PDAM efficiency and financial and operational performance 
include cost recovery tariffs, improved revenue collection, enhanced financial management and 
accounting, nonrevenue water (NRW)4 reduction, expanded coverage with service connections, 
and stronger customer orientation. The TA will assess the financial status and fiscal capacity of 
participating  RGs,  and  will  identify  capacity  development  programs  for  enhancing  their 
creditworthiness and to facilitate their future access to commercial funding sources, including 
potential bond financing. The TA will review the potential for private sector participation in the 
water supply and sanitation sector, and recommend options for private sector involvement in the 
WSSP. 
8.  ADB has provided assistance for improving urban and rural water supply and sanitation 
in Indonesia since 1972: 8 water supply and sanitation loan projects for about $317 million, and 
15 TA projects for about $5.9 million. Additional financing for water supply and sanitation 
improvement was provided through urban development projects. The World Bank has provided 
additional support by financing water supply and sanitation and urban development projects, 
and is currently processing a loan for the Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Improvement and 
Expansion Project, which is similar to the proposed WSSP in objectives and scope. Other major 
sources  of  funding  for  the  sector  include  the  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development (USAID), Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), Australian Agency for 
International  Development  (AusAID),  and  Germany  through  Gesellschaft  für  Technische 
Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) and Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW).  
9.  The project design builds on lessons learned through the long-term involvement of ADB 
in the sector in Indonesia. Main lessons include (i) lack of operation and management capacity, 
particularly in small PDAMs; (ii) tariffs that do not allow cost recovery, resulting in poor service 
delivery;  (iii)  lack  of  public  participation;  (iv)  limited  support  for  financial  and  managerial 
autonomy  of  PDAMs  by  RGs;  and  (v)  small  contract  packages  that  result  in  inefficient 
procurement and are difficult to monitor. 
                                                 
4  NRW is composed of (i) physical losses caused by leakages; and (ii) commercial losses resulting from illegal

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The TA is designed to meet the growing demand of the urban population for improved 
water supply and sanitation service delivery, in line with current Government policy and the 
requirements  of  ADB.  Particular  attention  will  be  given  to  the  need  for  PDAM  reform, 
governance, improved water supply and sanitation, health, decentralization, legal requirements 
including  for  funds  channeling  (KMK  35),5  and  transparent  and  efficient  procurement  and 
implementation arrangements. The Project will support the Government in its effort to achieve 
the water related MDG (footnote 2).  
11.  The objectives of the TA are to (i) develop the WSSP to a level of detail suitable for 
consideration by ADB for funding, (ii) prepare SPARs for up to 15 PDAMs and RGs, and (iii) 
prepare institutional-development and capacity-building programs.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  TA  will  require  a  proactive  and  demand-based  approach,  working  in  close 
consultation with relevant parties at central and regional government levels, and will be carried 
out in two phases, which may partly overlap. 
13.  Phase 1. Phase 1 activities are to (i) gather and review sector relevant information, data, 
and reports; (ii) identify potential issues and hindrances that may affect successful and timely 
processing of the WSSP; (iii) develop criteria for selecting PDAMs and RGs; (iv) review and 
update data on PDAM and RG indebtedness and arrears in debt service;6 and (v) assist the 
Government, ADB, and other stakeholders in selecting suitable PDAMs and RGs, based on 
their  firm  commitment.  Activities  will  be  complemented  by  workshops  and  seminars  to 
disseminate information, clarify issues, and ensure that all stakeholders, particularly PDAMs 
and RGs, are fully informed about the objectives, scope, and methodology of the Project, 
required counterpart contributions and other commitments, initial financing arrangements, and 
roles and responsibilities of all parties.  
14.  Criteria for selecting PDAMs and RGs will be based on (i) their fiscal capacity and 
commitment to reform, (ii) governance criteria, (iii) focus on serving low-income communities, 
(iv)  restructured  arrears  in  debt  service,  (v)  well-defined  investment  needs,  (vi)  project 
preparedness, and (vii) geographic focus of ADB. Performance and governance criteria are 
particularly emphasized. To have efficient implementation arrangements for both the TA and the 
anticipated loan project, the WSSP will be confined to no more than five provinces. Phase 1 will 
be completed within 2 months, and activities may partly overlap with those of phase 2. 
15.  Phase 2. Phase 2 will include (i) preparing SPARs for up to 15 PDAMS and RGs, (ii) 
packaging the WSSP to a level of detail suitable for consideration by ADB for funding, (iii) 
developing  implementation  and  funds  channeling  arrangements,  (iv)  preparing  institutional-
development and capacity-building programs, and (v) supporting workshops and seminars.  
16.  The TA will be implemented following a bottom-up approach and a highly consultative 
process, enabling PDAMs, RGs and other stakeholders to take ownership of the SPARs and the

governance, (iii) financial and operational utility performance improvement, (iv) cost recovery 
tariffs, (v) corporatization of PDAMs, (vi) improved sanitation, (vii) health and hygiene, (viii) 
gender,  (ix)  indigenous  peoples,  (x)  environment,  (xi)  resettlement,  (xii)  private  sector 
participation,  (xiii)  enhancement  of  municipal  creditworthiness,  and  (xiv)  transparent  and 
efficient implementation and procurement arrangements. The TA will be prepared in accordance 
with relevant national standards and ADB requirements, policies, strategies, and guidelines.  
17.  In designing water supply system improvements, the consultant will consider reducing 
nonrevenue water, extending the network to the urban poor, mobilizing idle system capacity, 
adopting measures to facilitate installation of house connections, enhancing cash flow, water 
bottling, water quality monitoring, improving energy efficiency, and developing water sources. 
Sanitation will address wastewater collection and treatment, including but not limited to septic 
tanks, septage treatment plants, and relevant maintenance equipment. In addition, options for 
and feasibility of transferring responsibility for sanitation to PDAMs will be assessed during 
project preparation. The consultant will develop capacity-building components, including but not 
limited to programs for improving PDAMs’ financial and operational performance and enhancing  
RGs’ creditworthiness.  
18.  Implementation and procurement arrangements for the ensuing loan project will include 
measures  to  improve  efficiency  and  transparency,  and  to  reduce  the  risk  of  fraud  and 
corruption. The TA will investigate an outsourced project management unit, independent audits 
of  financial  accounts  and  project  performance,  and  options  for  integrated  design-procure-
construct contract packages.  
19.  Current health and hygiene practices related to water supply and sanitation, and relevant 
awareness and education programs will be reviewed. The impact on health resulting from 
waterborne diseases, and practices and standards for water quality monitoring will be assessed. 
Capacity building developed under the Project will include information programs that will explain 
and advocate the benefits and importance of clean water supply and sanitation for health, 
especially for children and women. 
20.  Activities  under  phase  2  will  be  supported  by  workshops  and  seminars  aiming  at 
disseminating  information,  confirming  commitment,  discussing  of  common  issues  of  PDAM 
reform, developing institutional capacity, and implementation support. Workshop participation of 
representatives of successful water utilities from Indonesia and other countries of the region will 
be  considered,  for  sharing  good  practices  on  improved  financial  and  operational  utility 
performance, customer orientation, provision of services for the poor, and governance. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.125 million equivalent, comprising $462,000 in 
foreign exchange and $663,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance $900,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign currency cost and $438,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis, with 
$700,000 from the Government of the United Kingdom7 administered by ADB, and $200,000 
from ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the remaining local currency cost 
amounting to $225,000 equivalent, which covers office and support facilities, counterpart staff, 
administrative support, and local transportation for counterpart staff. The Government has been 
informed that financing of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. Details 
of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
                                                 
7  Provided by the Department for International Development (DFID).

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be the Directorate General for Urban and Rural 
Development (DGURD) of the Ministry of Settlement and Regional Infrastructure (MSRI). A 
project management unit (PMU) to be established within DGURD will be responsible for the 
technical and administrative aspects of the TA, and day-to-day decisions affecting its conduct. 
The PMU will include suitably qualified and experienced counterpart staff to work alongside the 
TA consultants. The TA consultants will provide support to the head of the PMU, and will work in 
close collaboration with the counterpart team. A steering committee, chaired by DGURD and 
comprising senior officials from DGURD, BAPPENAS, MOF, Ministry of Health, Coordinating 
Ministry for Economic Affairs, Ministry of Home Affairs, and Indonesia Water Supply Association 
(PERPAMSI) will be established to provide guidance and oversee TA implementation. The 
committee will meet monthly. 
23.  It is estimated that the TA will require a team of 4 international consultants and 15 
domestic consultants to be engaged by ADB for a total of 76 person-months: 18 international, 
and 58 domestic. The consultants will be engaged through a firm in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, using the quality-and cost-based selection method and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. DGURD will be 
responsible for providing the agreed upon counterpart resources. The proposed outline terms of 
reference for the Consultants are in Appendix 4. All procurement under the TA will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Procurement. 
24.  The TA is expected to be implemented over 7 months, starting in January 2005 and with 
completion by August 2005. The consultants will prepare (i) an inception report within the first 
month, (ii) an interim report by the end of month 3, (iii) a draft final report by the end of month 5, 
(iv) a final report within 1 month after receiving comments, and (v) monthly progress reports. 
Tripartite review meetings will be held after inception, at the interim report stage, and at the draft 
final report stage.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom, and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of 
Indonesia for preparing the Water Supply and Sanitation Project, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
The Indonesia Poverty Assessment notes: “Access to effective sanitation systems and clean water is an important 
determinant of health status and is a fundamental determinant of the quality of life. It is also predominantly the poor 
who lack this access. Providing these facilities is hence an appropriate antipoverty measure.” The poverty partnership 
agreement notes the importance of increasing basic services, including water supply and sanitation, to the poor. The 
recently released Indonesia Progress Report on the Millennium Development Goals notes that urban population 
growth is rapidly outstripping access to piped water in urban areas. Sanitation is lagging further behind. To meet the 
MDG targets for clean water and sanitation in urban areas, considerable reform is required for financing investment, 
creating  professionally  and  independently  managed  and  operated  regional  water  supply  enterprises  (PDAMs), 
charging appropriate tariffs, developing incentives to connect the poor, and raising awareness and demand for 
sanitation.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
A.  Background and Objectives 
1.  Indonesia is urbanizing rapidly. The urban population is projected to increase from the 
current 45% of the total population to 60% by 2025, and in absolute terms will double to 160 
million. Most urban public enterprises, notably local water supply enterprises, are in crisis and 
poor sanitation services are the cause of severe urban pollution. The objectives of consulting 
services are to (i) develop the proposed water supply and sanitation project (WSSP) to a level of 
detail suitable for consideration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for funding, (ii) prepare 
subproject  appraisal  reports  (SPARs)  for  up  to  15  water  utilities  (PDAMs)  and  regional 
governments (RGs), and (iii) prepare institutional-development and capacity-building programs 
addressing sector reform and governance. 
B.  Scope of Work 
2.  The tasks of the consultant will require a proactive and demand-based approach in close 
consultation  with  relevant  parties  at  the  central  and  regional  governments.  The  project 
preparatory  technical assistance (TA)  will  be  carried  out  in  two  phases,  which  may  partly 
overlap. 
3.  Phase 1 to be completed within 2 months will include (i) review and collection of data; (ii) 
dissemination of information; (iii) workshops, seminars, and consultations, (iv) initial assessment 
of potential issues, hindrances, and risks; and (v) selection of PDAMs and RGs, which could 
serve as drivers of change for reform in the sector, suitable to participate in the WSSP, their 
financial status, and priority investment and institutional development requirements.  
4.  Phase  2  will  include  (i)  preparation  of  SPARs  for  up  to  15  PDAMs  and  RGs,  (ii) 
packaging of the WSSP to a level of detail suitable for consideration by ADB for funding, (iii) 
development  of  implementation  and  funds  channeling  arrangements,  (iv)  preparation  of 
institutional-development and capacity-building programs, and (v) workshops and seminars.  
5.  The consultant will develop the Project following a bottom-up approach and a highly 
consultative  process,  and  in  accordance  with  relevant  national  legal  requirements1  and 
standards,2 and ADB requirements, policies, strategies, and guidelines. It is estimated that a 
team of 4 international consultants and 15 domestic consultants will be engaged for a total of 76 
person-months (18 international and 58 domestic).  
6.  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Specialist  and  Team  Leader.  One  international 
consultant (7 person-months), in cooperation with three domestic consultants (6 person-months 
each), will carry out the following tasks.   
(i)  Assist the Directorate General for Urban and Rural Development (DGURD),3 the 
Government's  Executing  Agency,  and  other  relevant  stakeholders  to  select 
suitable RGs and PDAMs for participation in the Project, including formulating 
selection criteria. 
                                                 
1  Including but not limited to funds channeling arrangements as defined in the Ministry of Finance Decree No. 
35/2003 (KMK 35).  
2  Including project readiness criteria under the 2002 Country Portfolio Performance Review. 
3  Within the Ministry of Settlement and Regional Infrastructure.

12  Appendix 4 
(ii)  Prepare  a  program  to  disseminate  information  to  RGs,  PDAMs,  government 
agencies,  consumers,  and  other  stakeholders  and  conduct  workshops  and 
seminars.4 
(iii)  For each participating PDAM and RG, carry out water and sanitation audits 
including  surveys  of  consumers  and  the  unserved  for  information  on  water 
source, access, availability, quality, quantity, and price, as well as wastewater 
collection and treatment. Undertake measurements, surveys, and water quality 
analysis, as required. 
(iv)  Prepare SPARs for up to 15 RGs and PDAMs. Assess the technical, financial, 
social,  and  economic  feasibility  and  priority  of  each  subproject  component, 
including  the  phasing  of  investments.  In  designing  water  supply  system 
improvements,  consider  among  other  components  (a)  nonrevenue  water 
reduction, (b) network extension to the urban poor, (c) mobilizing idle system 
capacity, (d) measures to facilitate installation of house connections, (e) cash 
flow  enhancement,  (f)  water  bottling,  (g)  energy  efficiency,  (h)  water  quality 
monitoring, and (i) water sources. Sanitation will address wastewater collection 
and treatment, including but not limited to (a) septic tanks, (b) septage treatment 
plants,  and  (c)  relevant  maintenance  equipment.  Assess  options  and  the 
feasibility of transferring responsibility for sanitation to PDAMs. Prepare project 
cost estimates for each RG and PDAM using the COSTAB software. 
(v)  Prepare  detailed  project  implementation  and  phasing  schedules  for  each 
component,  and  investigate  options  for  integrated  design-procure-construct 
packages to improve implementation efficiency, and have preferably only one 
contract  per  PDAM  or  RG.  Prepare  recommendations  for  overall  project 
implementation, administration, auditing, monitoring and evaluation. Investigate 
options for an outsourced project management unit. 
(vi)  Prepare  an  effective  project  performance  monitoring  system  (PPMS)  that 
includes monitoring of the project's performance, benefits, and impact on poverty 
reduction.  Together  with  other  team  members,  identify  the  training  needs  to 
strengthen the capacity of PDAMs and RGs, including but not limited to financial 
and operational performance improvement program (FOPIP) for PDAMs, and 
municipal creditworthiness enhancement programs.  
(vii)  Together with other consultant team members, review the current involvement of 
the  private  sector  in  providing  water  supply  and  sanitation  services,  and 
recommend  the  most  suitable  options  for  private  sector  participation  (i.e., 
management contracts).  
7.  Financial and Economic Analyst. One international consultant (4 person-months), in 
cooperation  with  two  domestic  financial–economic  analysts  (4  person-months  each)  and  1 
domestic economic analyst (4 person-months), will carry out the following tasks. 
(i)  Assess  in  detail  each  participating  PDAM’s  its  (a)  financial  management 
capacity, and (b) financial state including income statements, balance sheet and 
cash flow statements, and existing loan repayments. Analyze major constraints 
to their financial sustainability, and the degree of operational subsidies from the 
                                                 
4  The consultant may consider inviting representatives of successful  water utilities from Indonesia and other 
countries of Southeast Asia to share their experience in improving financial and operational utility performance, 
customer orientation, providing services for the poor, and governance.

Appendix 4  13 
local  government.  Prepare  measures  for  restructuring  nonperforming  loans.5 
Prepare  financial  projections  including  revenues,  operating  and  capital 
expenditures, and debt repayment. 
(ii)  Review  existing  water  tariffs,  identify  any  deficiencies,  and  suggest 
improvements  in  line  with  ADB's  position  on  tariffs,  as  summarized  in  ERD 
Technical Note #9. Analyze the effective collection rates for various consumer 
types, including collection in cash and in kind (if any) as well as their existing 
collection  rates  and  ways  to  improve  collection  of  current  bills  and  arrears. 
Assess  the  costs  of  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  and  level  of  cost 
recovery, and determine tariffs needed to ensure sustainable operations. 
(iii)  Review the impact and affordability of introducing full and partial cost recovery in 
water supply services in the participating PDAMs. Assess the demand on the 
basis of price, income, water quality, water quantity consumed, and access to 
alternative supplies. Analyze affordability of water and sanitation services and 
assess willingness to pay for them.  
(iv)  Assess in detail each participating RG’s its (a) financial management capacity, 
and  (b)  financial  performance  including  borrowing  capacity  and  debt  service 
coverage ratios relating to existing and potential new loans. Prepare financial 
projections  including  revenues,  operating  and  capital  expenditures,  and  debt 
repayment. 
(v)  Prepare the financial arrangements specifying the foreign exchange and local 
currency costs to be financed by ADB, central Government, RGs, PDAMs, other 
agencies, and beneficiaries, as applicable.  
(vi)  Together  with  other  team  members,  prepare  detailed  cost  estimates  and 
financing plans for each of the project components and the Project as a whole 
using the COSTAB software.  
(vii)  Conduct comprehensive economic and financial analyses for each subproject 
and  the  overall  Project,  using  relevant  ADB  guidelines,  handbooks,  and 
standards. Based on past and projected financial statements, compute relevant 
financial indicators, including, but not limited to, debt service coverage ratios, and 
operating ratios. Compute for each subproject and the overall project financial 
internal rates of return (FIRRs), weighted average cost of capital (WACC), and 
economic internal rates of return (EIRRs).  
(viii)  Together  with  the  social  development  specialist,  analyze  the  impact  of  the 
Project on poverty reduction. Review in detail the distribution of project benefits, 
net economic benefits, and poverty impact ratio.   
(ix)  Together  with  other  team  members,  prepare  a  FOPIP  for  PDAMs,  and  a 
municipal creditworthiness enhancement program for the RGs. 
8.  Institutional Development Specialist. One international consultant (3 person-months), 
in  cooperation  with  two  domestic  consultants  (3  person-months  each),  will  carry  out  the 
following tasks: 
                                                 
5  The consultant will liaise with other consultants working on relevant technical assistance projects, including 
ADB.2002. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Indonesia for Support for Regional Government Borrowing 
System. Manila.

14  Appendix 4 
(i)  Hold discussions with the participating RGs and PDAMs to identify key issues 
and obtain their views on capacity-building needs, and develop concepts for the 
design of the capacity-building components. 
(ii)  Outline a system of accreditation of personnel and organizations (including civil 
works contractors and consulting firms) that will guarantee competencies and 
levels of performance through accreditation.  
(iii)  Prepare action plans for each PDAM and RG within the framework of ongoing 
deregulation measures, designing an open competency-based organization and 
staffing  system  leading  to  recommended  local  government  regulation  as 
necessary.  
(iv)  With other members of the preparation team, develop a FOPIP for participating 
PDAMs, and outline training programs, recommended interventions that should 
be included in the project, and estimated costs. 
9.  Social Development Specialist. One international consultant (4 person-months), in 
cooperation with four domestic consultants (3 person-months each), will carry out the following 
tasks. 
(i)  Identify key stakeholders (poor and vulnerable groups in particular) and their 
project-related interests, identify the likely barriers to their participation in and 
benefiting from project resources, and suggest possible strategies for addressing 
their concerns. Identify factors affecting project risk and viability. Prepare an 
initial stakeholder analysis and a draft participation plan, according to Appendix 
4.4. of ADB's Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis.  
(ii)  Undertake focus group discussions with beneficiaries and affected people in the 
subproject areas to identify key constraints to, and related economic costs of, 
access of the poor to potable water supply services. Assess the role of water 
users’  councils  and  how  they  should  be  involved  in  project  design  and 
implementation. 
(iii)  Using ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis, carry out household 
surveys in collaboration with other consultant team members, and prepare a 
socioeconomic profile of the target population, including an assessment of its 
requirements and preferences in water supply and sanitation services, social 
customs and practices relevant to the proposed project design, specifically their 
ability and willingness to pay for the services. Particular attention should be given 
to mitigating any adverse impacts of the subprojects and the overall Project on 
specific communities or groups, particularly the poor.  
(iv)  Prepare a gender analysis of the Project according to the guidelines in Appendix 
5.1 of ADB's Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis, and help the team leader 
identify project design elements (policy, investment, or implementation) that (a) 
will enable women to participate in and benefit from the Project, and (b) have the 
potential to exclude women from participating in or benefiting from the Project.  
(v)  Recommend  subproject  interventions  to  address  gender  imbalances,  and 
interventions  to support  other  vulnerable  groups,  which will  result  in  poverty 
reduction and social strategy under the project. 
(vi)  Develop and recommend mechanisms and procedures for public consultation 
and  community  participation  in  project  planning,  operation  and  maintenance, 
project  implementation  and  management,  particularly  in  relation  to  levels  of

Appendix 4  15 
service performance, tariffs, and environmental protection. Assess whether or not 
there is a role for nongovernment organizations (NGOs) in project activities. 
Carry out public consultations, including with NGOs.  
(vii)  Assess the need for land acquisition in the Project. If land acquisition is required 
for a selected subproject, prepare a resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s 
policy  on  resettlement.  Prepare  a  resettlement  framework  for  the  Project  in 
accordance with ADB requirements. 
(viii)  Assess the need for preparing an indigenous people’s development framework, 
development  plan,  or  specific  action  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  policy  on 
indigenous peoples. Prepare the necessary framework, plan, and specific action 
in accordance with ADB’s requirements. 
(ix)  Together with the financial and economic analyst and following ADB’s Handbook 
on Poverty and Social Analysis, prepare a poverty impact assessment. Explain 
the poverty definition used and estimate the number of poor beneficiaries.  
(x)  Justify the Project from the point of view of social dimensions (social impact, 
impact on poverty, and gender and development). 
10.  Environmental Specialist. Two domestic consultants (3 person-months each) will carry 
out the following tasks: 
(i)  Prepare  an  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  or  environmental  impact 
assessment (EIA), if warranted, for each individual subproject, and a summary 
IEE or a summary EIA for the whole Project, in accordance with the applicable 
national standards, and in line with ADB requirements.  
(ii)  Conduct public consultation at least once for each participating PDAM and RG. 
11.  Health and Hygiene Specialist. One domestic consultant (4 person-months) will carry 
out the following tasks: 
(i)  Assess current health and hygiene practices connected with water supply and 
sanitation, and review relevant awareness and education programs. 
(ii)  Assess health impacts resulting from waterborne diseases, and practices and 
standards for water quality monitoring. 
(iii)  Outline information programs that will explain and advocate the benefits and 
importance for health, especially of children and women, of clean water supply 
and sanitation. Have one program for families and communities, and one for 
decision makers within the RGs.  
C.  Reporting  
12.  The assignment will last for 7 months, and the consultant will prepare the following 
reports: (i) inception report by end of month 1, (ii) interim report by end of month 3, (iii) draft final 
report by end of month 5, (iv) final report 1 month after receiving comments, (v) monthly 
progress reports (2–3 pages), and (vi) other reports as may reasonably be required.
